H0.text: What was invented in the 1940s by Percy Spencer, an American self-taught engineer from Howland, Maine, who was building magnetrons for radar sets. Microwave Oven

H1.text: What was invented in the 1940s by Percy Spencer, an American self-taught engineer from Howland, Maine, who was building magnetrons for radar sets. Radar Detector

H2.text: What was invented in the 1940s by Percy Spencer, an American self-taught engineer from Howland, Maine, who was building magnetrons for radar sets. High-Power Transmitter

H3.text: What was invented in the 1940s by Percy Spencer, an American self-taught engineer from Howland, Maine, who was building magnetrons for radar sets. Radarange

A4.text: Raytheon filed a U.S. Patent application on October 8, 1945, for a microwave cooking oven.

A5.text: In 1967 the first more affordable, $495 (equivalent to $4,668 in 2024), and reasonably sized (counterâ€‘top) Radarange brand microwave oven was made available for sale, produced by Amana (a division of Raytheon).

A6.text: Percy Spencer noticed that microwaves from an active radar set he was working on started to melt a candy bar he had in his pocket.

A7.text: In 1947, Raytheon built the 'Radarange', the first commercially available microwave oven.

A8.text: U.S. patent 2,495,429: Percy Spencer's original patent
